Entries.default:
"Be with you in just a - almost had it, damn your eyes." 

The sun-scarred dwarf gingerly picks at a splinter in his thumb, muttering.
"Radora must think I work for free."
"[Player Ship] could use some lumber and tar if you have it on hand."
"Farewell."
"Back for more, are you? Haven't had enough of old Zamar yet?" Worrying his beard with one hand, he gestures for you to speak with the other.
"Hope you find a way out of this."
"Aye, hope and a hammer are all I've got left." He shrugs and sighs at his workshop.
"Ahoy there. Any news worth telling?" Zamar dusts off his shoulders.
"I spoke with Captain Radora."
"The Príncipi won't be bothering you anymore."
"I spoke to the Príncipi on your behalf."
"You actually confronted those feral cats?"
"I think you're better off taking their deal."
"On second thought, I'll return later."

"Best news I've heard since I arrived on this rock!" Zamar lowers his hands. They shake like they don't know where to go next.

They go back up to his beard, this time less frenzied.
"She was robbed. Don't hold it against her."
"The money's gone, but I'm going to hunt down whoever took it."
"Someone's feeling bold to prey on a captain in Queen's Berth."
"Matters being what they are, Radora's commission is yours if you can afford it." Zamar smooths down his mustache and dislodges a small puff of sawdust.
"I needed COIN, not a middleman to negotiate with cutthroats!" He pulls a small flintlock from his belt and holds it pointed at the ground.
"Put down the gun. The deal is already struck."
"The Príncipi won't be thugs forever. Give them a chance."
"Maybe I'm not as trusting as some kith."
"To stake my future on pirates without even a country to call their own?"
"Radora hasn't got any money. The Príncipi are your only choice."
His chest rises and falls with heavy breaths as he lifts the gun halfway.
"I'd like to see your goods."
"I might be interested in buying Radora's commission."
"Come take a look." He steps aside to show you the contents of his crates.
"You again?" Zamar worries the edges of a fresh bruise around his eye.
"Business comes and goes like the tide. What can I do for you?" Zamar fluffs up his beard and winks at you.
"You do that, then." Shaking his head, Zamar dismisses you with a wave.
"I've been in this business too long to fall for bullying and cheap tricks."
"Not interested."

"You... you will? I mean, you will!" 

He snatches your hand and shakes it with two quick pumps.
"Well, I'm here if you ever change your mind." He shrugs and sighs.
"But the Príncipi claimed her already. Looks like you missed your chance."
"Cotta's dead... So you went through all that trouble for nothing?" Zamar frowns to himself and tugs on a twisted strand of beard.
"You're welcome."
"Don't flatter yourself - I did this for my own amusement."
"Remind me never to ask about the details." Rubbing his brow, Zamar gestures for you to speak freely.
"Why haven't you settled your differences already?"
"Because I've got a backlog of work through the next turning of the Wheel!"
[Say nothing.]
"And I'm old, damn it. These hips won't carry me to the Mare and back without a fight."

"The Príncipi have their shipwright, and may Ondra take them for it." 

He grabs a fistful of his beard and grunts, pulling away with a few strands of hair. Opening his palm, Zamar lets them drift away with the wind.
"I convinced Cotta to leave you alone."
"What can I do for you?"
"Having trouble with a client?"
"And before you ask, that's after materials, labor, and fees." He counts off his fingers before nestling them back in his beard.
"While I'm up to my nose in debt, the Wild Mare gobbles up her coin."
"And now PIRATES are holding my feet to the fire over some sham of a deal." Zamar winces and tugs harder on his beard in self-administered punishment.
"If someone bought Radora's commission, would that solve your money problems?"
"Aye, but only once she fesses up that she doesn't have the coin." Sifting among his beard, Zamar finds a black hair and plucks it out.
"Call me a fool for holding out hope. She's an old client and a friend."
"I don't have that kind of money."
"Thought not. Something about Queen's Berth bleeds us all dry."
"If you're starved for coin, useful folk tend to get paid around here." He gestures to the greater district, wincing at it.
"If you can make [Player Ship] seaworthy again, do it."
"I'll have you squared away in no time. Let me go over exactly what we'll need to do..."
"Ach, poor thing. The archipelago takes a tithe on every ship it meets." Zamar scratches his jaw and glances toward your vessel.
"Let me take a look at your ships, Zamar."
"No small investment. Let me show you what I have available."
"I had other questions."
"As you will. Just let me know when that ship of yours is ready for a going over."
"That's an outrageous price!"
"Tell it to my suppliers. Everyone needs raw materials, and I don't see many trees."
"You underestimate how hard the Príncipi are working to make cooperation your only recourse."
"That doesn't make it right!" His grip on the gun squeezes tighter.
"You're meant to take this deal before they offer you a worse one."
"Do you want to see what happens when they run out of patience?"
"A thousand is plenty less than I offered the seasoned captain." One of Zamar's bushy eyebrows rises over the other.
"What say I take a couple hundred off the price? Fair payment for the splinter."
"My hands are tied. Sorry."
"You seem to know the value of an honest day's work. Tear five hundred off the cost."
"I'll take it."
"I'll take it."
"Has she sobered up yet, or do we need to shake her by her ankles?"
"Forget Radora. I'm the one who settled your pirate problem."
"Aye, but..." Scratching at the back of his neck, Zamar glances farther down the thoroughfare of Queen's Berth.
"Coin lost in Queen's Berth tends to stay lost, but I trust you."
"Just carry that sum around, do you?" Zamar blinks as he accepts many armloads of coin.

"Hazard of the work, really."

He gives up with a frustrated grunt, shaking his hand.
"Came in on the sloop? I can hammer your ship together if you're apt to pay me for it." Zamar bares his teeth and grinds them hard enough to sound over the noise of the dock.
"That'll be the Iron Thunderer, a cannon well-deserving of her name." Zamar beams with pride.
"For a thousand pires she'll crack a hull, scour a sail, or splinter a deck like an imp with something to prove."
"I'll take it."
"This is my reward for helping you?"
"Your vessel will spit fire like a wurm with a belly full of fire kelp." He snaps his fingers at one of his attendants and points at your ship.
"What kind of 'deal' are these pirates offering?"
"One where I mend Príncipi ships and no others." Zamar pulls his hair back from his face with both hands, but it only returns to its tangled configuration.
"Bastards are driving away business until I give in."
"Less gobbling in there than you'd think."
"It all comes down to blasted pands and pires in the end, doesn't it?" Zamar spits toward the dock pilings and glances back at the work still to be done.
"Aye. Captain Radora hasn't paid me for her commissioned firepower." Zamar pulls at the end of his beard and winces.
"Maybe she doesn't stand up to Rauatai standards, but she's got heart."

"Glad to see a client eye to eye for a change."

He gives up with a frustrated grunt, shaking his hand.
"Same could be said of the Wahaki tribe, and look what happened to them." Grinning, Maia winks down at Ishiza.
Sparing a sharp glare at Maia, Zamar turns his focus over to you.
"But your friend's mouth has raised the price by five hundred." He folds his arms and tips his head at Maia.
"Here you go."
"Maia didn't say anything that offensive."
"I don't ask my clients their business because it gets in the way of mine."
"The Huana are good customers."
"I'll see that you get your money's worth, captain." Maia holds Zamar's gaze.
"I don't have that kind of coin."
"More's the pity. Come back when you do."
Sighing through his nose, Zamar squeezes his eyes shut.
"If it's between my life and my dignity..." Gritting his teeth, he thumbs the hammer down and tucks the firearm back into his belt.
"Cotta's not a bad guy. His wolf is cute."
"You're siding with that crook?"
"And what's a wolf really, but a dog that ain't been pet enough?"
"But maybe I ought to be."
"I won't be held down by schemers and killers."
[Lie] "She said that I should help myself to her commission."
"Robbed? Abydon's fist!" Blinking, Zamar glances past you and swallows.
"Did she, now?" Zamar smooths down some of his nostril hairs so they blend in with the rest of his mustache.
"Eh. Much as I want to help Radora, it's time I started looking after myself."
"For the Iron Thunderer."
"For the Iron Thunderer."
"Times being what they are, the work will cost upwards of... ten thousand."
"If I don't get Radora's payment, I might as well start carving my suolenet."
"Per complanca, don't be ridiculous!"
"And if you're a slow worker, maybe they'll only kill you?" Maia sighs through her nose.
"If it gets me a discount on your labor, I could hunt down Radora."
"You'd do that? A fair price goes without saying, cully." Zamar untangles his hand from his beard to link his thumb and forefinger with a wink.
"What of Captain Radora?" Zamar pulls the end of his mustache taut.
"I don't have enough coin to repair [Player Ship] yet."
"Aye, but you'll know where to find me when you do."
"These old joints don't carry me far." He rubs his hip and grimaces at the passing city folk.
"What in Abydon's stinking furnace do you want?"

"Cats be sacred shipboard, you know. Wouldn't've taken you for one to be painting the Príncipi all godly."

Serafen smirks, arms akimbo.

"Folk shore-side sometimes stick 'em in the stewpot. See if that strikes you for something weighty." 

Zamar rolls his eyes. He crosses his arms and looks past Serafen at you.
"And here I'd've thought a shipwright would be eager for an exclusive contract. In particular one with clients disposed towards getting their ships shot to shit and shot again."

"Folk like that come by coin easy, only to lose it all again. 

"I'm not sinking my business on the say-so of a pack of puffed-up bilge rats."
"In other words, we need to go to the Wild Mare. Well, that's just fine and dandy."
"Mare's a right popular place. There are worst favors I could ask."
"A lot of both. I've served on flotsam that I trusted more."
"Only tithes we ought to be paying's to Gaun! And you want ten thousand?!"

"No easy task, putting a seaworthy vessel together.

"Now, you want to try your hand at praying for a ship, I won't stop you."
"Abydon's iron scrote, dwarf! Are you aiming to drive away our custom?" His arms spread wide, his hands open and upturned.
"Ten thousand's a fair rate, and you'll not find better."
"Your trials will define you. Take strength from that."
"Strength? I have strength!" He holds out his shaking hands.
"About Captain Radora..."
